summary: The document is a comprehensive collection of personnel and administrative records detailing David L. Christ's career within the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) from the 1950s to the 1970s. It encompasses his roles, responsibilities, promotions, salary adjustments, and retirement, highlighting his significant contributions to technical and research programs, including electronics, acoustics, and applied physics. The records also shed light on his involvement in clandestine services and operational cover arrangements, underscoring his participation in sensitive and classified activities. His performance evaluations consistently commend his leadership, technical competence, and administrative capabilities, while also noting areas for improvement such as the need for more field experience. The document includes various forms, reports, and memoranda, such as fitness reports, personal history statements, and security clearance approvals, providing a detailed overview of his career progression and contributions to the CIA.
key_findings: David L. Christ held key positions within the CIA, including Deputy Chief of the Applied Physics Branch and Chief of the Technical Applications Group, contributing significantly to intelligence program development and technical innovations.
He was awarded the Intelligence Medal of Merit for his meritorious service from 1950 to 1970 and retired under the CIA Retirement and Disability System in November 1970.

Christ's performance was highly rated, with commendations for leadership and technical proficiency, though some reports suggested the need for more field experience and better program management balance.
He was involved in the recruitment and supervision of professionals in fields like electronics and acoustics, and his work included the development of technical and administrative procedures.
Christ was recommended for overseas assignments to gain firsthand field experience and was considered for leadership roles in overseas technical components.
His application for a position as an Electronics Engineer in the Office of Policy Coordination was granted provisional clearance, with specific conditions pending a full security investigation.
